question: <strong>How do Prokaryotic cell differ from eukaryotic cell? [AI 99]
answer:
Nucleus

  • Devoid of nuclear membraneand nucleolus 
  • No deoxyribonucleoproteins i.e. their nucleic DNA is not associated with basic protein (histone). 
  • The genome consists of a single molecule double stranded DNA arranged in the form of a circle.
  • Mitotic division does not occur and these divide by binary fission.

Cytoplasm 

  • No protoplasmic streaming 
  • Absence of endoplasmic reticulum Mitochondria, lysosomes and golgi apparatus. 

Chemical composition 

  • Cell wall of prokaryotes contain Muramic acid and peptidoglycan (no sterols) while cell wall of eukaryotes contains sterols.

question: <strong>What is the composition of cell membrane?
answer: The plasma membrane is about 40% lipid and 60% protein, [AIIMS 94] but these proportions vary greatly. Most of the lipids in the plasma membrane are phospholipids.

question: <strong>What are heterochromatin and euchromatin?
answer:

question: <strong>What are polysomes?
answer:
• Polyribosomes (or polysomes) are a cluster of ribosomes, bound to a mRNA molecule.

question: <strong>What are the functions of Smooth endoplasmic reticulum? [BPKIHS 08]

question: <strong>What is the function of Golgi apparatus?
answer:
• The proteins that are synthesized by rough endoplasmic reticulum must next be sent to the Golgi apparatus. [BPKIHS 12]
  • Newly synthesized proteins enter into the Cis-Golgi, sortingand the glycosylation of proteins [AI 08,14] occur in medial golgi and Packaging occurs in Trans-golgi for secretion as secretory vesicles.

question: <strong>Which of the following is the marker of Golgi apparatus? [AI 95, IOM 11]
answer:

  • D) Galactosyl transferase

question: <strong>What is Hyperproinsulinemia?
answer: Elevated level of proinsulin in the serum resulting from failure of a peptidase to cleave proinsulin and C-peptide in the Golgi apparatus, resulting in NIDDM.

question: <strong>How are lysosomes produced?
answer:
The synthesis of lysosomal hydrolase occurs in the RER, the hydrolases are transferred to the Golgi apparatus, where they are modified and packaged into lysosomes.

They are produced by budding from the trans side of golgi apparatus.

question: <strong>What are peroxisomes?
answer:
• They are specialized type of lysosomes in a way that they contain various enzymes involved in various stages of degradation.
  • The major product they degrade is hydrogen peroxide and the major enzyme thus is catalase.

question: <strong>Name the functions of peroxisomes.
answer:
• Degradation of hydrogen peroxide
  • Beta-oxidation of very long fatty acids
  • Bile acid and cholesterol synthesis

question: <strong>What is Zellweger syndrome?
answer: Zellweger syndrome, also called cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, is a rare congenital disorder, characterized by the reduction or absence of functional peroxisomes in the cells of an individual.

question: <strong>Where are the enzymes required for electron transport system located in mitochondria?

answer:

question: <strong>What is difference between basement membrane and basal lamina?
answer:
• The basement membrane is the fusion of two lamina, the basal lamina and the reticular lamina (or lamina reticularis).
  • The basal lamina is a layer of extracellular matrix secreted by the epithelial cells, on which the epithelium sits and a reticular lamina secreted by other cells.
  • The term "basal lamina" is usually used with electron microscopy, while the term "basement membrane" is usually used with light microscopy.

question: <strong>What are desmosomes and hemidesmosomes?
answer:
• A desmosome (desmos, band or dense, soma, body), also known as macula adherens (plural: maculae adherentes) is a cell structure for cell-to-cell adhesion.
  • Desmosomes help to resist shearing forces and are found in simple and stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Hemidesmosome are half of desmosome and help to bind the epithelial cell with the basement membrane of the cell.

question: <strong>What are cadherins?
answer:

[@Ca d herins - Ca dependent adherin molecule]

question: <strong>What is collagen?
answer:
• Collagen is the major macromolecule of connective tissue and is the most common protein in the animal world.
  • The most important property of collagen molecule is triple helix structure[AIIMS 95, UP 99] made of three polypeptide subunits.
  • Collagen consists of glycine, proline and 4-hydroxyproline. [UP 00]

question: <strong>What are the steps in synthesis of collagen?
answer: Collagen precursors are produced in rough endoplasmic reticulum of fibroblasts ? hydroxylation that requires vitamin C and glycosylation in golgi apparatus ? triple helix formation in golgi apparatus ? released from golgi as procollagen ? propeptides are removed forming tropocollagen ? tropocollagen are assembled to form collagen fibre.

question: <strong>What is the defect in Ehlers Danlos syndrome?
answer:
• Conversion of procollagen to tropocollagen is defective.
  • Forms fragile skin, hyperextensible joints, varicose veins.

question: <strong>What are the types of collagen?
answer:
Collagen

Features

Type I

Strongest; Present in strong tissues like bONEs, ligaments, tendon, skin, sclera, teeth, mature scar

Type II

Weaker; Present in cartilages (carTWOlage), [IOM 02] intervertebral disc

Type III

Much weaker; Present in Blood vessels, forms reticular fibres in various organs; Stained with PAS and silver salts 

Type IV

Weakest of all collagens

Supports only a row of epithelial cells as in basement membrane [IOM 09]

[Note: Collagenase (metalloenzyme containing zinc) breaks type III collagen in granulation tissue to replace by type I collagen(stronger)]

question: <strong>Which enzyme mediates the degradation of basement membrane?
answer:
Basement membrane consists of network of amorphous non-fibrillar collagen (mostly type IV).

Matrix metalloproteinases [AI 07] is a family of enzymes that are involved in degradation of basement membrane.

[Note: Type IV collagenase is present in neutrophil and malignant cell - so have similar mechanism of invading the basement membrane for chemotaxis and metastases respectively]

question: <strong>Which collagen is defective in Alport syndrome?
answer:
Type IV collagen

Alport syndrome is due to mutation of COL4A3, COL4A4, COL4A5 gene involved in collagen biosynthesis, which leads to poor type IV collagen network, which is an important structural component of basement membranes in the kidney, inner ear and eye.

It causes glomerulonephritis, hearing loss, cataract, keratoconus, lenticonus, etc.

[@ Alports syndrome -  Al-four-t’s Syndrome - type IV]

question: <strong>What is the defect in Marfan syndrome?

Cardiovascular signs and conditions

question: <strong>Normal metacarpal index is:

question: <strong>What are examples of Glycosaminoglycan?
answer:
Glycosaminoglycan contains two glucose molecules (disaccharide) along with amino group, thus the name glycosaminoglycan.

GAG is either sulphated or non-sulphated.

  • Sulphated GAG: Chondroitin sulphate, Heparin sulphate, Dermatan sulphate and Keratin sulphate
  • Non sulphated include: Hyaluronic acid

Presence of sulphate makes the GAG negatively charged and thus repels negatively charged particles.

question: <strong>What are Hyaluronic acids?
answer: • Hyaluronic acids are non-sulphated GAGs that form extracellular matrix.

question: <strong>What are proteoglycans?  [AI 07]
answer:
• Proteoglycans are macromolecules in which a coreprotein is attached covalently to one or more glycosaminoglycan chains (complex carbohydrate).
  • They are sulphated GAGs.
  • They are chondroitin sulphate, heparin sulphate, dermatan sulphate and keratin sulphate.
  • Proteoglycans hold largeamount of water and occupy space. They are negatively charged.

question: <strong>Why are proteins not filtered in Glomerulosa?
answer: Proteins are negatively charged and the basement membranes of podocytes contain heparin sulphate that is negatively charged and thus they repel protein.

question: <strong>What are labile cells?
answer:
Labile cells are the cells that continue to proliferate throughout the life, replacing the cells that are continually being destroyed. Labile cells in body are

  • Lining mucosa of all the excretory ducts of glands of the body such as salivary glands, pancreas, and biliary tract
  • The columnar epithelium of GI tract, uterus, fallopian tube and transitional epithelium of the urinary tract

question: <strong>What are primordial germ cells?
answer:
The primordial germ cells origin from the wall of yolk sac that is endodermal. They migrate into the gonadal portion of urogenital ridge. So, all the components are mesodermal in origin but the germ cells are endodermal in origin.

Genital and urological structures develop from urogenital ridge located in the posterior wall of embryo abdomen.

Role of primordial germ cells – As the germ cells reach the gonadal portion of urogenital ridge, they form gamete in the future. They induce the mesoderm to develop into the gonad.  Thus, although the mesodermal cells are destined to develop into gonad, they cannot differentiate into gonad if not induced by primordial germ cells. 

In the Y chromosome, there is SRY (Sex determining Region of Y) gene, and this gene codes for Testis Determining Factor (TDF). In the presence of TDF, that gonad becomes the testis, and in absence of TDF, it becomes the ovary. In other words, the embryo is preprogrammed to become a female, and if there is no stimulus, it will become female. A female is not female because she has XX chromosome, she is female because she does not have Y chromosome.

question: <strong>What are the factors that make male organs in a preprogrammed female gonad?
answer:
Testis determining factor

From SRY gene of y chromosome makes testis. 

Testosterone secreted from Leydig cells

Forms duct system of male reproductive system.

Mullerian Inhibiting factor (MIF) from Sertoli cells

That inhibits the mullerian tract.

 
  • The inhibition is compulsory. If there is no inhibition, the preprogrammed embryo forms all female organs. 
  • In absence of SRY gene, there is no production of TDF. Testis does not develop and there is no production of testosterone to produce male organs. There are no Sertoli cells to produce MIF, female organs develop as preprogrammed.

question: <strong>Which cell in the body is tetraploid?
answer:
• Primary spermatocyte or oocyte is tetraploid.
  • After DNA replication, DNA amount is doubled to form tetraploid cells.
  • Though there are still 46 chromosomes, each chromosome has twice much DNA after DNA replication, so the cell is tetraploid.

question: <strong>How many sperm and ovum does the primary spermatocyte and primary oocyte give?
answer: One Primary oocyte gives one ovum. There is unequal first meiotic cell division of primary oocyte. One cell receives almost all cytoplasm, and the other cell thus converts into first polar body, same for secondary oocyte. Thus, only one ovum is produced. One Primary spermatocyte gives 4 sperms.

question: <strong>What is the difference in mitosis division in other somatic cells and Zygote?
answer:
• In somatic cells, there is cell growth in between the cell division. When a cell divides, it results in half the size of mother cell. The daughter cell grows to a definite size before it again divides.
  • In zygote, there is no growth of the daughter cells. There is only the division of the cell. So, when a zygote divides into two cells, each cell is half the size of zygote, and when these cells further divide, to form 4 and 8 cells, the size of the resulting cells become 1/4th and 1/8th the size of the zygote. Thus there is no increase in volume. The zygote and morula are of same size. This type of cell division is also called as Cleavage division. As the cleavage proceeds, a solid mass of sixteen cell[UP 94] is formed. This is called Morula.

question: <strong>When does uteroplacental circulation begin?
answer: • On day 11-12, [IOM 11, KU 13] primitive uteroplacental circulation forms with oxygenated maternal blood arriving via spiral arterioles, seeping into the lacunae and leaving via endometrial venous capillaries.

question: <strong>What are the events in second week of embryo?
answer:
Formation of early placenta

Formation of double layered embryo

  • Epiblast – give future embryo
  • Hypoblast – degenerate

The cell layers between epiblast and hypoblast are separable except at a point called as prechordal plate. It is the site of future mouth. It determines the polarity of the circular disc of cells that has no polarity. By determining the head end, we can now determine the left, right, head and tail end of embryo.

question: <strong>What is primitive groove or streak?
answer: Towards the tail end of epiblast forms a groove in the midline, called primitive streak. Here, the cells of the epiblast from left and right migrates to the midline and goes beneath to the hypoblast.

question: <strong>How are endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm formed?
answer:
• The cells from the epiblast migrate down through the primitive streak to the site of hypoblast. The cells of hypoblast degenerate and are replaced by the migrated cells to form endoderm.
  • The cells of epiblast that migrate and remain in the position between epiblast and hypoblast form middle layer. The cells that migrate either in left or right side to form mesoderm.
  • The remaining cells in epiblast form ectoderm.

question: <strong>How is Notochord formed?
answer:
• The cells from the epiblast that migrate through primitive streak and remain between epiblast and hypoblast in the left and right form middle layer. The cells at the site of middle layer that remain in the midline form Notochord. 
  • Notochord gives Nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disc.

question: <strong>What are the sub-divisions of ectoderm?
answer:
• Neuroectoderm – occupy midline
  • Neural crest ectoderm – occupy side of neuroectoderm cells
  • Surface ectoderm

question: <strong>What is gastroschisis?

question: <strong>How do Prokaryotic cell differ from eukaryotic cell? [AI 99]

Nucleus

  • Devoid of nuclear membraneand nucleolus 
  • No deoxyribonucleoproteins i.e. their nucleic DNA is not associated with basic protein (histone). 
  • The genome consists of a single molecule double stranded DNA arranged in the form of a circle.
  • Mitotic division does not occur and these divide by binary fission.

Cytoplasm

  • Absence of endoplasmic reticulum Mitochondria, lysosomes and golgi apparatus. 

Chemical composition 

  • Cell wall of prokaryotes contain Muramic acid and peptidoglycan (no sterols) while cell wall of eukaryotes contains sterols.

question: <strong>What is Hyperproinsulinemia?

question: <strong>How are lysosomes produced?

question: <strong>What are peroxisomes?
answer:

question: <strong>What is Zellweger syndrome?

question: <strong>What is difference between basement membrane and basal lamina?
answer:
• The basement membrane is the fusion of two lamina, the basal lamina and the reticular lamina (or lamina reticularis).
  • The basal lamina is a layer of extracellular matrix secreted by the epithelial cells, on which the epithelium sits and a reticular lamina secreted by other cells.
  • The term "basal lamina" is usually used with electron microscopy, while the term "basement membrane" is usually used with light microscopy.

question: <strong>What are desmosomes and hemidesmosomes?
answer:

  • Desmosomes help to resist shearing forces and are found in simple and stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Hemidesmosome are half of desmosome and help to bind the epithelial cell with the basement membrane of the cell.

question: <strong>What are cadherins?

question: <strong>What is collagen?
answer:
• Collagen is the major macromolecule of connective tissue and is the most common protein in the animal world.
  • The most important property of collagen molecule is triple helix structure[AIIMS 95, UP 99] made of three polypeptide subunits.
  • Collagen consists of glycine, proline and 4-hydroxyproline. [UP 00]

question: <strong>What are the steps in synthesis of collagen?
answer: Collagen precursors are produced in rough endoplasmic reticulum of fibroblasts ? hydroxylation that requires vitamin C and glycosylation in golgi apparatus ? triple helix formation in golgi apparatus ? released from golgi as procollagen ? propeptides are removed forming tropocollagen ? tropocollagen are assembled to form collagen fibre.

question: <strong>What is the defect in Ehlers Danlos syndrome?
answer:
• Conversion of procollagen to tropocollagen is defective.
  • Forms fragile skin, hyperextensible joints, varicose veins.

question: <strong>What are the types of collagen?
answer:
Collagen

Features

Type I

Strongest; Present in strong tissues like bONEs, ligaments, tendon, skin, sclera, teeth, mature scar

Type II

Weaker; Present in cartilages (carTWOlage), [IOM 02] intervertebral disc

Type III

Much weaker; Present in Blood vessels, forms reticular fibres in various organs; Stained with PAS and silver salts 

Type IV

Weakest of all collagens

Supports only a row of epithelial cells as in basement membrane [IOM 09]

[Note: Collagenase (metalloenzyme containing zinc) breaks type III collagen in granulation tissue to replace by type I collagen(stronger)]

question: <strong>Which enzyme mediates the degradation of basement membrane?
answer:
Basement membrane consists of network of amorphous non-fibrillar collagen (mostly type IV).

Matrix metalloproteinases [AI 07] is a family of enzymes that are involved in degradation of basement membrane.

[Note: Type IV collagenase is present in neutrophil and malignant cell - so have similar mechanism of invading the basement membrane for chemotaxis and metastases respectively]

question: <strong>Which collagen is defective in Alport syndrome?
answer:
Type IV collagen

Alport syndrome is due to mutation of COL4A3, COL4A4, COL4A5 gene involved in collagen biosynthesis, which leads to poor type IV collagen network, which is an important structural component of basement membranes in the kidney, inner ear and eye.

It causes glomerulonephritis, hearing loss, cataract, keratoconus, lenticonus, etc.

[@ Alports syndrome -  Al-four-t’s Syndrome - type IV]

question: <strong>What is the defect in Marfan syndrome?

question: <strong>What are examples of Glycosaminoglycan?
answer:

GAG is either sulphated or non-sulphated.

  • Sulphated GAG: Chondroitin sulphate, Heparin sulphate, Dermatan sulphate and Keratin sulphate

Presence of sulphate makes the GAG negatively charged and thus repels negatively charged particles.

question: <strong>What are proteoglycans?  [AI 07]

  • Proteoglycans hold largeamount of water and occupy space. They are negatively charged.

question: <strong>What are primordial germ cells?
answer:
The primordial germ cells origin from the wall of yolk sac that is endodermal. They migrate into the gonadal portion of urogenital ridge. So, all the components are mesodermal in origin but the germ cells are endodermal in origin.

Genital and urological structures develop from urogenital ridge located in the posterior wall of embryo abdomen.

Role of primordial germ cells – As the germ cells reach the gonadal portion of urogenital ridge, they form gamete in the future. They induce the mesoderm to develop into the gonad.  Thus, although the mesodermal cells are destined to develop into gonad, they cannot differentiate into gonad if not induced by primordial germ cells. 

In the Y chromosome, there is SRY (Sex determining Region of Y) gene, and this gene codes for Testis Determining Factor (TDF). In the presence of TDF, that gonad becomes the testis, and in absence of TDF, it becomes the ovary. In other words, the embryo is preprogrammed to become a female, and if there is no stimulus, it will become female. A female is not female because she has XX chromosome, she is female because she does not have Y chromosome.

question: <strong>What are the factors that make male organs in a preprogrammed female gonad?
answer:
Testis determining factor

From SRY gene of y chromosome makes testis. 

Testosterone secreted from Leydig cells

Forms duct system of male reproductive system.

Mullerian Inhibiting factor (MIF) from Sertoli cells

That inhibits the mullerian tract.

 
  • The inhibition is compulsory. If there is no inhibition, the preprogrammed embryo forms all female organs. 
  • In absence of SRY gene, there is no production of TDF. Testis does not develop and there is no production of testosterone to produce male organs. There are no Sertoli cells to produce MIF, female organs develop as preprogrammed.

question: <strong>Which cell in the body is tetraploid?
answer:

question: <strong>How many sperm and ovum does the primary spermatocyte and primary oocyte give?
answer: One Primary oocyte gives one ovum. There is unequal first meiotic cell division of primary oocyte. One cell receives almost all cytoplasm, and the other cell thus converts into first polar body, same for secondary oocyte. Thus, only one ovum is produced. One Primary spermatocyte gives 4 sperms.

question: <strong>What is the difference in mitosis division in other somatic cells and Zygote?
answer:
• In somatic cells, there is cell growth in between the cell division. When a cell divides, it results in half the size of mother cell. The daughter cell grows to a definite size before it again divides.
  • In zygote, there is no growth of the daughter cells. There is only the division of the cell. So, when a zygote divides into two cells, each cell is half the size of zygote, and when these cells further divide, to form 4 and 8 cells, the size of the resulting cells become 1/4th and 1/8th the size of the zygote. Thus there is no increase in volume. The zygote and morula are of same size. This type of cell division is also called as Cleavage division. As the cleavage proceeds, a solid mass of sixteen cell[UP 94] is formed. This is called Morula.

question: <strong>What is blastocyst?

question: <strong>When does uteroplacental circulation begin?

question: <strong>What are the events in second week of embryo?
answer:
Formation of early placenta

Formation of double layered embryo

  • Epiblast – give future embryo
  • Hypoblast – degenerate

The cell layers between epiblast and hypoblast are separable except at a point called as prechordal plate. It is the site of future mouth. It determines the polarity of the circular disc of cells that has no polarity. By determining the head end, we can now determine the left, right, head and tail end of embryo.

question: <strong>What is primitive groove or streak?
answer: Towards the tail end of epiblast forms a groove in the midline, called primitive streak. Here, the cells of the epiblast from left and right migrates to the midline and goes beneath to the hypoblast.

question: <strong>How are endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm formed?
answer:
• The cells from the epiblast migrate down through the primitive streak to the site of hypoblast. The cells of hypoblast degenerate and are replaced by the migrated cells to form endoderm.
  • The cells of epiblast that migrate and remain in the position between epiblast and hypoblast form middle layer. The cells that migrate either in left or right side to form mesoderm.
  • The remaining cells in epiblast form ectoderm.

question: <strong>How is Notochord formed?
answer:
• The cells from the epiblast that migrate through primitive streak and remain between epiblast and hypoblast in the left and right form middle layer. The cells at the site of middle layer that remain in the midline form Notochord. 
  • Notochord gives Nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disc.

question: <strong>What are the sub-divisions of ectoderm?

  • Neural crest ectoderm – occupy side of neuroectoderm cells

question: <strong>How do Prokaryotic cell differ from eukaryotic cell? [AI 99]
answer:
Nucleus

  • Devoid of nuclear membraneand nucleolus 
  • No deoxyribonucleoproteins i.e. their nucleic DNA is not associated with basic protein (histone). 
  • The genome consists of a single molecule double stranded DNA arranged in the form of a circle.
  • Mitotic division does not occur and these divide by binary fission.

Cytoplasm 

  • No protoplasmic streaming 
  • Absence of endoplasmic reticulum Mitochondria, lysosomes and golgi apparatus. 

Chemical composition 

  • Cell wall of prokaryotes contain Muramic acid and peptidoglycan (no sterols) while cell wall of eukaryotes contains sterols.

question: <strong>What is difference between basement membrane and basal lamina?
answer:
• The basement membrane is the fusion of two lamina, the basal lamina and the reticular lamina (or lamina reticularis).
  • The basal lamina is a layer of extracellular matrix secreted by the epithelial cells, on which the epithelium sits and a reticular lamina secreted by other cells.
  • The term "basal lamina" is usually used with electron microscopy, while the term "basement membrane" is usually used with light microscopy.

question: <strong>What are desmosomes and hemidesmosomes?

  • Desmosomes help to resist shearing forces and are found in simple and stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Hemidesmosome are half of desmosome and help to bind the epithelial cell with the basement membrane of the cell.

question: <strong>What are cadherins?

question: <strong>What is collagen?
answer:

question: <strong>What are the steps in synthesis of collagen?
answer: Collagen precursors are produced in rough endoplasmic reticulum of fibroblasts ? hydroxylation that requires vitamin C and glycosylation in golgi apparatus ? triple helix formation in golgi apparatus ? released from golgi as procollagen ? propeptides are removed forming tropocollagen ? tropocollagen are assembled to form collagen fibre.

question: <strong>What is the defect in Ehlers Danlos syndrome?

question: <strong>What are the types of collagen?
answer:
Collagen

Features

Type I

Strongest; Present in strong tissues like bONEs, ligaments, tendon, skin, sclera, teeth, mature scar

Type II

Weaker; Present in cartilages (carTWOlage), [IOM 02] intervertebral disc

Type III

Much weaker; Present in Blood vessels, forms reticular fibres in various organs; Stained with PAS and silver salts

Weakest of all collagens

Supports only a row of epithelial cells as in basement membrane [IOM 09]

question: <strong>Which enzyme mediates the degradation of basement membrane?
answer:

question: <strong>Which collagen is defective in Alport syndrome?

Type IV collagen

Alport syndrome is due to mutation of COL4A3, COL4A4, COL4A5 gene involved in collagen biosynthesis, which leads to poor type IV collagen network, which is an important structural component of basement membranes in the kidney, inner ear and eye.

It causes glomerulonephritis, hearing loss, cataract, keratoconus, lenticonus, etc.

question: <strong>What is the defect in Marfan syndrome?

question: <strong>What are examples of Glycosaminoglycan?

  • Proteoglycans hold largeamount of water and occupy space. They are negatively charged.

question: <strong>What are primordial germ cells?
answer:
The primordial germ cells origin from the wall of yolk sac that is endodermal. They migrate into the gonadal portion of urogenital ridge. So, all the components are mesodermal in origin but the germ cells are endodermal in origin.

Genital and urological structures develop from urogenital ridge located in the posterior wall of embryo abdomen.

Role of primordial germ cells – As the germ cells reach the gonadal portion of urogenital ridge, they form gamete in the future. They induce the mesoderm to develop into the gonad.  Thus, although the mesodermal cells are destined to develop into gonad, they cannot differentiate into gonad if not induced by primordial germ cells. 

In the Y chromosome, there is SRY (Sex determining Region of Y) gene, and this gene codes for Testis Determining Factor (TDF). In the presence of TDF, that gonad becomes the testis, and in absence of TDF, it becomes the ovary. In other words, the embryo is preprogrammed to become a female, and if there is no stimulus, it will become female. A female is not female because she has XX chromosome, she is female because she does not have Y chromosome.

question: <strong>What are the factors that make male organs in a preprogrammed female gonad?
answer:
Testis determining factor

From SRY gene of y chromosome makes testis. 

Testosterone secreted from Leydig cells

Forms duct system of male reproductive system.

Mullerian Inhibiting factor (MIF) from Sertoli cells

That inhibits the mullerian tract.

 
  • The inhibition is compulsory. If there is no inhibition, the preprogrammed embryo forms all female organs. 
  • In absence of SRY gene, there is no production of TDF. Testis does not develop and there is no production of testosterone to produce male organs. There are no Sertoli cells to produce MIF, female organs develop as preprogrammed.

question: <strong>Which cell in the body is tetraploid?
answer:
• Primary spermatocyte or oocyte is tetraploid.
  • After DNA replication, DNA amount is doubled to form tetraploid cells.
  • Though there are still 46 chromosomes, each chromosome has twice much DNA after DNA replication, so the cell is tetraploid.

question: <strong>How many sperm and ovum does the primary spermatocyte and primary oocyte give?
answer: One Primary oocyte gives one ovum. There is unequal first meiotic cell division of primary oocyte. One cell receives almost all cytoplasm, and the other cell thus converts into first polar body, same for secondary oocyte. Thus, only one ovum is produced. One Primary spermatocyte gives 4 sperms.

question: <strong>What is the difference in mitosis division in other somatic cells and Zygote?
answer:
• In somatic cells, there is cell growth in between the cell division. When a cell divides, it results in half the size of mother cell. The daughter cell grows to a definite size before it again divides.
  • In zygote, there is no growth of the daughter cells. There is only the division of the cell. So, when a zygote divides into two cells, each cell is half the size of zygote, and when these cells further divide, to form 4 and 8 cells, the size of the resulting cells become 1/4th and 1/8th the size of the zygote. Thus there is no increase in volume. The zygote and morula are of same size. This type of cell division is also called as Cleavage division. As the cleavage proceeds, a solid mass of sixteen cell[UP 94] is formed. This is called Morula.

question: <strong>What is blastocyst?

    2. Trophoblast

question: <strong>When does uteroplacental circulation begin?
answer: • On day 11-12, [IOM 11, KU 13] primitive uteroplacental circulation forms with oxygenated maternal blood arriving via spiral arterioles, seeping into the lacunae and leaving via endometrial venous capillaries.

question: <strong>What are the events in second week of embryo?
answer:
Formation of early placenta

Formation of double layered embryo

  • Epiblast – give future embryo
  • Hypoblast – degenerate

The cell layers between epiblast and hypoblast are separable except at a point called as prechordal plate. It is the site of future mouth. It determines the polarity of the circular disc of cells that has no polarity. By determining the head end, we can now determine the left, right, head and tail end of embryo.

question: <strong>What is primitive groove or streak?
answer: Towards the tail end of epiblast forms a groove in the midline, called primitive streak. Here, the cells of the epiblast from left and right migrates to the midline and goes beneath to the hypoblast.

question: <strong>How are endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm formed?
answer:
• The cells from the epiblast migrate down through the primitive streak to the site of hypoblast. The cells of hypoblast degenerate and are replaced by the migrated cells to form endoderm.
  • The cells of epiblast that migrate and remain in the position between epiblast and hypoblast form middle layer. The cells that migrate either in left or right side to form mesoderm.
  • The remaining cells in epiblast form ectoderm.

question: <strong>How is Notochord formed?
answer:
• The cells from the epiblast that migrate through primitive streak and remain between epiblast and hypoblast in the left and right form middle layer. The cells at the site of middle layer that remain in the midline form Notochord. 
  • Notochord gives Nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disc.

question: <strong>What are the sub-divisions of ectoderm?

  • Neural crest ectoderm – occupy side of neuroectoderm cells
  • Surface ectoderm

question: <strong>What is gastroschisis?

question: <strong>How do Prokaryotic cell differ from eukaryotic cell? [AI 99]
answer:
Nucleus

  • Devoid of nuclear membraneand nucleolus 
  • No deoxyribonucleoproteins i.e. their nucleic DNA is not associated with basic protein (histone). 
  • The genome consists of a single molecule double stranded DNA arranged in the form of a circle.
  • Mitotic division does not occur and these divide by binary fission.

Cytoplasm 

  • No protoplasmic streaming 
  • Absence of endoplasmic reticulum Mitochondria, lysosomes and golgi apparatus. 

Chemical composition 

  • Cell wall of prokaryotes contain Muramic acid and peptidoglycan (no sterols) while cell wall of eukaryotes contains sterols.

  • Some consider them specialized microvilli.

question: <strong> What is the ATP splitting enzyme in cilia?
answer:
Dynein is a very large force generating protein [AI 01] that has a molecular configuration similar to arms. Contraction of these arms facilitates the movement of cilia and flagella of bacteria.

Kinesin also has similar activity.

question: <strong>What are the components of basement membrane?

question: <strong>What is difference between basement membrane and basal lamina?
answer:
• The basement membrane is the fusion of two lamina, the basal lamina and the reticular lamina (or lamina reticularis).
  • The basal lamina is a layer of extracellular matrix secreted by the epithelial cells, on which the epithelium sits and a reticular lamina secreted by other cells.
  • The term "basal lamina" is usually used with electron microscopy, while the term "basement membrane" is usually used with light microscopy.

question: <strong>What are desmosomes and hemidesmosomes?
answer:
• A desmosome (desmos, band or dense, soma, body), also known as macula adherens (plural: maculae adherentes) is a cell structure for cell-to-cell adhesion.
  • Desmosomes help to resist shearing forces and are found in simple and stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Hemidesmosome are half of desmosome and help to bind the epithelial cell with the basement membrane of the cell.

question: <strong>What are cadherins?
answer:
• Cadherins are calcium dependent adhesion proteins that ensure the adhesion of cells within the tissues.
  • First step of invasion of malignant cells through an epithelium results from a loss of expression of cadherins that weakens the epithelium.

[@Ca d herins - Ca dependent adherin molecule]

question: <strong>Where are stratified cuboidal epithelium found?
answer: Duct of salivary gland and sweat gland. It is the only place where we find the stratified cuboidal epithelium.

question: <strong>Where are transitional epithelium found?
answer:
• Transitional epithelium occurs in ureters, urinary bladder and proximal (prostatic) urethra. [IOM 10]
  • Within the cytoplasm are fusiform vesicles lined by unit membranes, the inner lamellae of are similarly thickened.
  • These vesicles are probably formed by infolding of the plasma membrane, and their walls constitutereserve material [AI 03] used in rapid expansion of the cells.

question: <strong>What is the composition of extracellular matrix?
answer:

question: <strong>What is collagen?
answer:
• Collagen is the major macromolecule of connective tissue and is the most common protein in the animal world.
  • The most important property of collagen molecule is triple helix structure[AIIMS 95, UP 99] made of three polypeptide subunits.
  • Collagen consists of glycine, proline and 4-hydroxyproline. [UP 00]

question: <strong>What are the steps in synthesis of collagen?
answer: Collagen precursors are produced in rough endoplasmic reticulum of fibroblasts ? hydroxylation that requires vitamin C and glycosylation in golgi apparatus ? triple helix formation in golgi apparatus ? released from golgi as procollagen ? propeptides are removed forming tropocollagen ? tropocollagen are assembled to form collagen fibre.

question: <strong>What is the defect in Ehlers Danlos syndrome?
answer:
• Conversion of procollagen to tropocollagen is defective.
  • Forms fragile skin, hyperextensible joints, varicose veins.

question: <strong>What are the types of collagen?
answer:
Collagen

Features

Type I

Strongest; Present in strong tissues like bONEs, ligaments, tendon, skin, sclera, teeth, mature scar

Type II

Weaker; Present in cartilages (carTWOlage), [IOM 02] intervertebral disc

Type III

Much weaker; Present in Blood vessels, forms reticular fibres in various organs; Stained with PAS and silver salts 

Type IV

Weakest of all collagens

Supports only a row of epithelial cells as in basement membrane [IOM 09]

[Note: Collagenase (metalloenzyme containing zinc) breaks type III collagen in granulation tissue to replace by type I collagen(stronger)]

question: <strong>Which enzyme mediates the degradation of basement membrane?
answer:
Basement membrane consists of network of amorphous non-fibrillar collagen (mostly type IV).

Matrix metalloproteinases [AI 07] is a family of enzymes that are involved in degradation of basement membrane.

[Note: Type IV collagenase is present in neutrophil and malignant cell - so have similar mechanism of invading the basement membrane for chemotaxis and metastases respectively]

question: <strong>Which collagen is defective in Alport syndrome?
answer:
Type IV collagen

Alport syndrome is due to mutation of COL4A3, COL4A4, COL4A5 gene involved in collagen biosynthesis, which leads to poor type IV collagen network, which is an important structural component of basement membranes in the kidney, inner ear and eye.

It causes glomerulonephritis, hearing loss, cataract, keratoconus, lenticonus, etc.

[@ Alports syndrome -  Al-four-t’s Syndrome - type IV]

question: <strong>Where are elastic fibres located?
answer:
• These fibres provide elasticity or resilience to the tissues meaning that they will return to their resting length after stretch.
  • They are present in lungs, blood vessels especially arteries and dermis of the skin.
  • Elastin + Fibrillin =elastin fibres

question: <strong>What is the defect in Marfan syndrome?
answer:
Marfan’s Syndrome is associated with a gene defect in Fibrillin-1 protein [AI 14] located in chromosome 15, that causes significant weakening in elastic tissue.

[@MarFaN = Mutation FibrilliN, FifteeN]

question: <strong>What are the features of Marfan's syndrome? [AI 94, AIIMS 95]
answer:
Musculoskeletal signs and conditions - 

o    Long, thin extremities (arachnodactyly)

o    Tall body habitus 

o    Pectus deformity 

o    High arched palate

o    Hyperextensible joints and ligaments

Ocular signs and conditions - 

o    Reduced vision as the result of subluxation of lens (ectopic lentis) [AI 93] 

o    Myopia 

o    Glaucoma 

o    Retinal detachment

Cardiovascular signs and conditions 

o    Aortic aneurysm that typically begin at the base of aorta [AI 95] 

o    Aortic regurgitation 

o    Mitral valve prolapse 

o    SABE

question: <strong>Normal metacarpal index is:

question: <strong>What are examples of Glycosaminoglycan?
answer:
Glycosaminoglycan contains two glucose molecules (disaccharide) along with amino group, thus the name glycosaminoglycan.

GAG is either sulphated or non-sulphated.

  • Sulphated GAG: Chondroitin sulphate, Heparin sulphate, Dermatan sulphate and Keratin sulphate
  • Non sulphated include: Hyaluronic acid

Presence of sulphate makes the GAG negatively charged and thus repels negatively charged particles.

question: <strong>What are Hyaluronic acids?
answer: • Hyaluronic acids are non-sulphated GAGs that form extracellular matrix.

question: <strong>What are proteoglycans?  [AI 07]
answer:
• Proteoglycans are macromolecules in which a coreprotein is attached covalently to one or more glycosaminoglycan chains (complex carbohydrate).
  • They are sulphated GAGs.
  • They are chondroitin sulphate, heparin sulphate, dermatan sulphate and keratin sulphate.
  • Proteoglycans hold largeamount of water and occupy space. They are negatively charged.

question: <strong>Why are proteins not filtered in Glomerulosa?
answer: Proteins are negatively charged and the basement membranes of podocytes contain heparin sulphate that is negatively charged and thus they repel protein.

question: <strong>What are labile cells?

Labile cells are the cells that continue to proliferate throughout the life, replacing the cells that are continually being destroyed. Labile cells in body are

  • The columnar epithelium of GI tract, uterus, fallopian tube and transitional epithelium of the urinary tract

question: <strong>What are primordial germ cells?
answer:
The primordial germ cells origin from the wall of yolk sac that is endodermal. They migrate into the gonadal portion of urogenital ridge. So, all the components are mesodermal in origin but the germ cells are endodermal in origin.

Genital and urological structures develop from urogenital ridge located in the posterior wall of embryo abdomen.

Role of primordial germ cells – As the germ cells reach the gonadal portion of urogenital ridge, they form gamete in the future. They induce the mesoderm to develop into the gonad.  Thus, although the mesodermal cells are destined to develop into gonad, they cannot differentiate into gonad if not induced by primordial germ cells. 

In the Y chromosome, there is SRY (Sex determining Region of Y) gene, and this gene codes for Testis Determining Factor (TDF). In the presence of TDF, that gonad becomes the testis, and in absence of TDF, it becomes the ovary. In other words, the embryo is preprogrammed to become a female, and if there is no stimulus, it will become female. A female is not female because she has XX chromosome, she is female because she does not have Y chromosome.

question: <strong>What are the factors that make male organs in a preprogrammed female gonad?
answer:
Testis determining factor

From SRY gene of y chromosome makes testis. 

Testosterone secreted from Leydig cells

Forms duct system of male reproductive system.

Mullerian Inhibiting factor (MIF) from Sertoli cells

That inhibits the mullerian tract.

 
  • The inhibition is compulsory. If there is no inhibition, the preprogrammed embryo forms all female organs. 
  • In absence of SRY gene, there is no production of TDF. Testis does not develop and there is no production of testosterone to produce male organs. There are no Sertoli cells to produce MIF, female organs develop as preprogrammed.

question: <strong>Which cell in the body is tetraploid?
answer:
• Primary spermatocyte or oocyte is tetraploid.
  • After DNA replication, DNA amount is doubled to form tetraploid cells.
  • Though there are still 46 chromosomes, each chromosome has twice much DNA after DNA replication, so the cell is tetraploid.

question: <strong>How many sperm and ovum does the primary spermatocyte and primary oocyte give?
answer: One Primary oocyte gives one ovum. There is unequal first meiotic cell division of primary oocyte. One cell receives almost all cytoplasm, and the other cell thus converts into first polar body, same for secondary oocyte. Thus, only one ovum is produced. One Primary spermatocyte gives 4 sperms.

question: <strong>What is the difference in mitosis division in other somatic cells and Zygote?
answer:
• In somatic cells, there is cell growth in between the cell division. When a cell divides, it results in half the size of mother cell. The daughter cell grows to a definite size before it again divides.
  • In zygote, there is no growth of the daughter cells. There is only the division of the cell. So, when a zygote divides into two cells, each cell is half the size of zygote, and when these cells further divide, to form 4 and 8 cells, the size of the resulting cells become 1/4th and 1/8th the size of the zygote. Thus there is no increase in volume. The zygote and morula are of same size. This type of cell division is also called as Cleavage division. As the cleavage proceeds, a solid mass of sixteen cell[UP 94] is formed. This is called Morula.

question: <strong>What is blastocyst?
answer:
• Blastocyst consists of an outer layer or trophoblast and inner layer of embryoblast. The enclosed cavity is blastocele.
  • Blastocystis the stage of implantation in the endometrium of uterus [AI 94] consisting of two cell groups.
    1. Embryoblast
    2. Trophoblast

question: <strong>What are the types of trophoblast?
answer:
Cytotrophoblast

Syncytiotrophoblast

  • Cells of cytotrophoblast are metabolically active and divide rapidly; the divided cells fuse and form syncytiotrophoblast.
  • Syncytiotrophoblast cause erosion of uterus for implantation and produce hCG hormone.

question: <strong>When does uteroplacental circulation begin?
answer: • On day 11-12, [IOM 11, KU 13] primitive uteroplacental circulation forms with oxygenated maternal blood arriving via spiral arterioles, seeping into the lacunae and leaving via endometrial venous capillaries.

question: <strong>What are the events in second week of embryo?
answer:
Formation of early placenta

Formation of double layered embryo

  • Epiblast – give future embryo
  • Hypoblast – degenerate

The cell layers between epiblast and hypoblast are separable except at a point called as prechordal plate. It is the site of future mouth. It determines the polarity of the circular disc of cells that has no polarity. By determining the head end, we can now determine the left, right, head and tail end of embryo.

question: <strong>What is primitive groove or streak?
answer: Towards the tail end of epiblast forms a groove in the midline, called primitive streak. Here, the cells of the epiblast from left and right migrates to the midline and goes beneath to the hypoblast.

question: <strong>How are endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm formed?
answer:
• The cells from the epiblast migrate down through the primitive streak to the site of hypoblast. The cells of hypoblast degenerate and are replaced by the migrated cells to form endoderm.
  • The cells of epiblast that migrate and remain in the position between epiblast and hypoblast form middle layer. The cells that migrate either in left or right side to form mesoderm.
  • The remaining cells in epiblast form ectoderm.

question: <strong>How is Notochord formed?
answer:
• The cells from the epiblast that migrate through primitive streak and remain between epiblast and hypoblast in the left and right form middle layer. The cells at the site of middle layer that remain in the midline form Notochord. 
  • Notochord gives Nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disc.

question: <strong>What are the sub-divisions of ectoderm?
answer:
• Neuroectoderm – occupy midline
  • Neural crest ectoderm – occupy side of neuroectoderm cells
  • Surface ectoderm

question: <strong>What is gastroschisis?
answer: Defect in fusion of the lateral body folds results in gastroschisis – abdominal viscera exit through a defect in the abdominal wall and are in the amniotic cavity.
